choices.text: It forms upper boundary of superior mediastinum
The ascending aorta begins at this level
It represent the disc between the fourth and fifth thoracic vertebrae posteriorly

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the marked structure in the figure?
questions.solution:
Marked structure is sternal angle/angle of Louis:

  • It is felt as a transverse ridge about 5 cm below the suprasternal notch.
  • It marks the manubriosternal joint, and lies at the level of the second costal cartilage anteriorly.
  • Vertebral level: The disc between the fourth and fifth thoracic vertebrae posteriorly (Option D).
  • It is secondary cartilaginous joint (So option A is false).
  • This is an important landmark for the following reasons.
    1. Beginning and termination of arch of aorta
    2. Tracheal bifurcation (carina)
    3. 2nd costosternal joint
    4. Confluence of azygous vein and SVC
    5. Junction of superior and inferior mediastinum
    6. Thoracic duct crosses from right to left
    7. Ligamentum arteriosum
  • Option B) - It forms the lower boundary of the superior mediatinum and not upper boundary
  • Option C) - ascending aorta ends and arch of aorta begins at this level

Topic: Thoracic cage

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 215

questions.text: What is the type and subtype of the joint marked in the figure below?
questions.solution:
• The marked joint in the figure is costovertebral joint.

The joints of thorax are as follows:

Majority - plane type of synovial joint (sternocostal,interchondral, costotransverse, costovertebral joints)

Exceptions-

  • 1st sternocostal joint - fibrous joint (synarthrosis joint)
  • Sternoclavicular joint - saddle type of synovial joint
  • Midline joints(manubriosternal joint and xiphisternal joint) - secondary cartilaginous joints
  • costochondral joint - primary cartilaginous joints

Option A) secondary cartilaginous joints - manubriosternal, xiphisternal, symphysis pubis

Option B) condylar type of synovial joint - temporomandibular joint , knee joint

Option C ) ellipsoid variety of synovial joint - wrist joint and metacarpophalangeal joint(MCP)

Topic: Joints of thorax

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 215 to 217

choices.text: The skin around umbilicus is supplied by T10 spinal segment
It lies at the level of the disc between the fourth and fifth lumbar vertebrae
It is important site of portocaval anastomoses
It is meeting pont of digestive, circulatory and nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about umbilicus?
questions.solution:
The umbilicus:

  • The umbilicus is the normal scar in the anterior abdominal wall formed by the remnants of the root of the umbilical cord.
  • The position of the umbilicus is variable. In healthy adults, it lies in the anterior median line, at the level of the disc between the third and fourth lumbar vertebrae (Option B).
  • It is lower in infants and in persons with a pendulous abdomen.
  • With reference to the lymphatic and venous drainage, the level of the umbilicus is a watershed. Lymph and venous blood flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus; and downwards below this plane. These do not normally cross umbilical plane.
  • The skin around the umbilicus is supplied by segment T10 of the spinal cord (Option A).
  • The umbilicus is one of the important sites at which tributaries of the portal vein anastomose with systemic veins (portocaval anastomoses) (Option C).
  • Umbilicus is the meeting point of the four (two lateral, head and tail) folds of embryonic plate.
  • This is also the meeting point of three systems, namely the digestive (vitellointestinal duct), the excretory (urachus), and vascular (umbilical vessels). So option D is false.

Topic: Anterior abdominal wall

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 25, 26

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of superior mesenteric artery?
questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery:

  • It is the artery of the midgut. It supplies all derivatives of the midgut.
  • The superior mesenteric artery arises from the front of the abdominal aorta, behind the body of the pancreas, at the level of vertebra L1 (Option A), one centimetre below the coeliac trunk.
  • At its origin, it lies first behind the body of the pancreas and then in front of the uncinate process. So carcinoma of uncinate process of pancreas can compress superior mesenteric vessels.

Vertebral level of other large vessels of abdomen:

Option B - gonadal artery - L2

Option C - inferior mesenteric artery - L3

Option d - Termination of abdominal aorta - lower border of of L4

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 323, 325, 328

choices.text: It passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the umbilicus
It passes through tip of ninth costal cartilage
Hila of left kidney lie on this plane
It passes through lower border of L1 vertebra

questions.text: Which of the following is false about transpyloric plane?
questions.solution:
The transpyloric plane:

  • It is also known as Addison plane.
  • It passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the pubic symphysis. So (Option A) is false.
  • Structures present at the level of transpyloric plane are:
    1. L1 vertebra(lower border)- Option D
    2. Neck of pancreas
    3. Hilum of left kidney- Option C
    4. Tip of 9th costal cartilage - Option B
    5. Origin of superior mesenteric artery
    6. Origin of renal arteries
    7. Formation of portal vein
    8. Termination of spinal cord

Topic: Anterior abdominal wall

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 271

questions.text: 12 years old boy met with an accident. He was taken to hospital. He had severe blunt trauma in abdomen. On CT scan it was seen that spleen is ruptured. Which of the following sign may be positive in that patient?
questions.solution:
• Rupture of spleen:
    • The spleen is the most frequently ruptured organ in the abdomen following severe external blow.
    • The pain is referred to the left shoulder due to irritation of the left dome of diaphragm by the splenic blood.
    • It is called 'Kehr's sign' (Option B).
  • Acute cholecystitis:
    • Murphy's sign (Option A): If the finger is pressed under the right costal margin at the tip of the 9th costal cartilage when the patient is asked to take a deep breath, she/he feels sharp pain and winces with a catch in the breath as the diseased gallbladder meets the examining finger.
  • Acute peritonitis:
    • Blumberg sign (option D): On palpation rebound tenderness in the abdomen.
  • Acute Appendicitis:
    • MacBurney's sign (Option C): On palpation maximum tenderness is elicited at McBurney's point which is marked on the surface by a point at the junction of medial two-third and lateral one-third of a line extending from the umbilicus to the right anterior superior iliac spine.

KEY TAKE AWAYS:

Most common organ injured in blunt trauma abdomen- spleen

Most common organ injured in penetrating trauma abdomen - liver

Most common organ injured in under water blast injury - small intestine

Splenic rupture can be spontaneous - infectious mononucleosis, so children diagnosed with infectious mononucleosis are told to avoid contact sports.

Topic: Abdominal organs

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 341, 317, 348

questions.text: 50 years male patient was diagnosed with the Addison's disease. He will be clinically having all of the following symptom, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• A number of clinical conditions may occur following lesions affecting the cortex or medulla of the suprarenal gland.
  • They are attributable to either excess or deficiency of secretions from respective parts of the gland.
  • Addison's disease: It occurs due to chronic insufficiency of cortical secretion.
    • Clinically, it presents as
    • Muscle weakness and wasting (Option A)
    • Joint pain
    • Weight loss
    • Increased pigmentation of skin (Option C)
    • Low blood pressure (So Option B is false)
    • Restlessness (Option D)
    • Tiredness
    • Mood changes (depression, anxiety or irritability)
    • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypertension is a feature of Cushing syndrome which is a cortisol excess state

Topic: Suprarenal glands

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 383, 384

questions.text: What is the approximate distance from upper central incisor to the pierecing of the diaphragm of the oesophagus in an adult human?
questions.solution:
• The esophagus is a narrow muscular tube extending from pharynx to the stomach.
  • It is about 25 cm long.

Normally, the oesophagus shows four constrictions.

  1. At the level of C6
    • Situated at cricopharyngeal junction
    • 6 inc/ 15 cm from upper central incisors
  2. At the level of T4
    • Constriction is due to crossing of arch of aorta
    • 9 inch / 22.5 cm from upper central incisors
  3. At the level of T6
    • Constriction due to crossing of left bronchus
    • 11 inch / 27.5 cm from upper central incisors
  4. At the level of T10
    • Due to esophagus passing through the esophageal orifice of diaphragm
    • 15 inch / 37.5 cm from upper central incisors (option C)

Topic: Oesophagus

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 299

questions.text: Which of the following sinus of the valsalva gives origin to left coronary sinus?
questions.solution:
Aortic Sinuses (Sinuses of the Valsalva):

  • The root of aorta presents three dilatations called aortic sinuses of Valsalva.
  • These positions are: anterior, left posterior, and right posterior
  • Anterior aortic sinus (Option A & B) gives origin to the right coronary artery.
    • Hence it is also called right coronary sinus.
  • Left posterior aortic sinus (option C) gives origin to the left coronary artery.
    • Hence it is also called left coronary sinus.
  • Right posterior aortic sinus (option D) does not give origin to any artery.
    • Hense it is termed non-coronary sinus.

Topic: The aorta

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 1, 4th Edition, Page Number 290

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extension/expansion of the external oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
Extensions/expansions of external oblique muscles:

  • Inguinal ligament:
    • It is the lower-free border of external oblique aponeurosis stretching between anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle.
    • It forms boundary for femoral triangle and inguinal canal.
    • The various extensions/expansions of the inguinal ligament are:
  • Lacunar ligament or Gimbernat's ligament (Option A):
    • From the medial end the deep fibres of the inguinal ligament curve horizontally backward to the medial part of the pecten pubis forming lacunar ligament.
    • This ligament is triangular in shape with apex attached to the pubic tubercle.
    • lateral edge forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal, which is the site of production of a femoral hernia.
  • Pectineal ligament or ligament of Cooper (Option B):
    • It is the extension of the posterior part of the lacunar ligament along the pecten pubis up to the iliopectineal eminence.
  • Reflected part of inguinal ligament: extension of inguinal ligament from pubic tubercle to linea alba
  • Ilioinguinal ligament (option C):
    • It is a fibrous band extending from the inferior aspect of the inguinal ligament to the iliopectineal eminence.

Conjoint tendon (falx inguinalis) (Option D):

  • It is formed by the fusion of lower aponeurotic fibres of internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles which arches over the spermatic cord
  • It is attached on to the pubic crest and medial part of the pectineal line (pecten pubis).

Topic: Muscles of anterior abdominal wall

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 2, 4th Edition, Page Number 33, 42, 43

questions.text: 35 years old men met with an accident. He had blunt trauma over upper part of abdomen. During laprotomy a hemangioma was found on left of the attachment of falciform ligament of liver. Surgeon dissected left medial couinaud's segments of liver, which segments dissected by surgeon?
questions.solution:
Couinaud's segments of liver:

  • On the basis portal vein (most important), hepatic vein, bile duct, hepatic artery (least important) the liver can be divided into the right and left functional lobes.
  • These do not correspond to the anatomical lobes of the liver.
  • The physiological lobes are separated by a plane passing on the cholecystocaval line
  • On the inferior surface, the plane passes through the fossa for the gallbladder; and on the posterior surface, it passes through the middle of the caudate lobe.
  • The right lobe is subdivided into anterior and posterior segments.
  • The left lobe into medial and lateral segments.
  • Thus there are four segments in the liver:
    • Right anterior (V and VIII) - Option D
    • Right posterior (VI and VII) - Option C
    • Left lateral (II and III) - Option B
    • Left medial (I and IV) - Option A
  • Just left to attachment of falciform ligament, left medial segment lies. So Surgeon dissected I and IV couinaud's segments of liver
  • The hepatic segments are of surgical importance. The hepatic veins tend to be intersegmental in their course.

Topic: The liver

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 1, 4th Edition, Page Number 104

questions.text: 25 years old male patient was undergone with cholecystectomy. During operation surgeon ligated pedicle of gallbladder in the hepatocystic triangle. All of the following structures are forming a boundary for that triangle, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Cystohepatic triangle:

  • It is bounded by:
    • On the right side by the cystic duct (Option A)
    • On the left side by common hepatic duct (Option B)
    • Above by inferior surface of the liver (option D)
    • The apex of triangle faces downward between the cystic and common hepatic ducts.
  • The contents of the triangle are right hepatic artery (Option C), cystic artery, and cystic lymph node of Lund.
  • It is in this triangle that most of aberrant segmental right hepatic ducts and arteries are usually encountered.
  • The accessory hepatic ducts terminate either into the gallbladder or into the common hepatic duct or even into the bile duct, and are responsible for oozing of bile from the wound after cholecystectomy.
  • The identification of cystohepatic triangle and its contents helps the surgeon to locate the pedicle of gallbladder and its ligation in cholecystectomy.
    • The errors in gallbladder surgery often occur from failure to appreciate the common variations of the extrahepatic biliary system.
    • This occurs especially when the right hepatic artery in this triangle presents a caterpillarlike loop called Moynihan's hump, which may be inadvertently clamped, ligated along with cystic pedicle, and cut leading to profuse bleeding.

Topic: The extrahepatic billiary apparatus

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 1, 4th Edition, Page Number 112, 113

questions.text: 45 years old male was admitted to hospital after acute myocardial infarction. He was undergone with angiography and diagnosed with right coronary dominance. Angiography revels that right coronary artery was blocked 100%. Which of the following artery is affected with the blood supply in this patient?
questions.solution:
Coronary dominance:

  • The origin, course, and distribution of the posterior interventricular artery are variable.
  • In right coronary dominance (as given in patient), the posterior interventricular artery (Option B) is a branch of the right coronary artery.
    • It is found in 90% of the individuals.
  • In left coronary dominance, the posterior interventricular artery arises from circumflex branch of the left coronary artery.
    • It is found in 10% of the individuals.

Branches of right coronary artery:

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral.
  • Right conus artery
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular artery (Option B): It arises close to the crux of heart and lies in the posterior interventricular
    • It gives septal branches to posterior one-third of interventricular septum.
    • It also supplies AV node.

Branches of left coronary artery:

  • Anterior interventricular artery (Option A): It is a large branch.
  • Anterior ventricular branches for the ventricles. The large branch is called diagonal artery (Option D).
  • Septal branches
  • Left conus artery
  • Circumflex artery (Option C): It is the terminal part of left coronary artery after it has given off the large anterior interventricular branch. Its branches are:
    • Left marginal artery
    • Anterior and posterior ventricular branches
    • Atrial branches which are in anterior, posterior and lateral groups.

Topic: The heart

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 1, 4th Edition, Page Number 279, 280
